Over a short timeframe of just one month, the status quo is a powerful predictor, as major shifts in wealth distribution are uncommon. This pulls the probability towards 'No'. However, the Bloomberg Billionaires Index is heavily populated by US citizens. It is highly probable that many US billionaires are ranked in the vicinity of the 250th spot (e.g., 240-260). The daily volatility of the market means that the exact ranking on any given day has a significant element of randomness. A small outperformance of a US-based company's stock or a favorable currency shift could easily move a US citizen into the 250th position. My probability of 40% reflects a balance between the strong anchor of the recent status quo ('No') and the high base rate of US citizens on the list, which suggests a non-trivial chance of a 'Yes' outcome due to normal market fluctuations. My forecast is not higher because the only direct evidence points to a 'No' outcome. It is not lower because ignoring the high density of US billionaires around this rank and the daily volatility would be a mistake. I would increase my probability if I saw data suggesting US markets were significantly outperforming global markets in June 2025. Conversely, I would decrease it if a non-US billionaire appeared to solidify their position at or near the 250th rank.
